Comments_List: I learnt how to read papers in a constructive way. I developed my presenting skills, with the project presentation and with the discussions during classes we had
I developed a great deal of knowledge on the empirical political economy literature.  I developed skills in analyzing this research, as well as conducting it myself.
I gained a deeper knowledge of the literature in main areas of empirical political economy, the submission process to journals, and how scholars ought approach research questions.
I liked to course a lot. I thought it is the only course where we learn how to read and discuss papers

The strengths of the course were the instructor and class engagement with the readings.  Professor Washington had many insightful critiques and comments on the readings.  There were no major weaknesses although sometimes I felt like the discussion in class could have benefited by focusing a bit more on the "big picture" and slightly less on the minutiae of the empirics/methods used in the paper.
I can't think of any ways it could be improved, I really liked it.
Absolutely. I think is the course were I learnt the most this semester
Yes, definitely.  I think this course would be valuable to any economics or political science student interested in political economy.
